Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Initial Appearance as to 2-Jose Gonzalez-Fuentes, 3- Madeline Fernandez-Guzman, 5-Ramon L. Massa-Gonzalez, 6-Janidel Pastrana-Gonzalez, 14-Heriberto Claudio-Abreu, 17-Alejandro Fraguada-Pena held on 8/7/2013. Present: AUSA Alberto Lopez, Teresa Zapata, SAUSA Victor Acevedo and Cesar Rivera. Defendants were provided with copy of the Indictment and advised as to the charges and their rights. After reviewing the CJA-23 form filled by defendant, the Court deemed it appropriate to appoint counsel. Defendant will be represented by counsel. Defendant ordered temporarily detained pending hearings. Arraignment/Detention set for 8/9/2013 at 1:30 PM in Courtroom 10 before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Initial Appearance as to 59-Edward O. Rodriguez- Santiago, 78-Hector Soto-Colon held on 8/7/2013. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Arraignment as to Steven Velez-Lopez (53) Count 1,2,3,4,5 held on 8/12/2013. Present: SAUSA Alberto Lopez and defense counsel Juan Milanes. Defendant assisted by Court Interpreter. USPO Carolina Aparicio also present. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment. Plea of Not Guilty is entered as to all counts. Defense is granted seven (7) days to obtain discovery and fourteen (14) days thereafter to file all motions. The case is referred to Judge Jay Garcia-Gregory for trial setting thereafter. As to detention, the defense requests that conditions of release be fashioned. Defendant's mother or uncle can be qualified as a third party custodian. Government has no objection that conditions of release be set. The Court sets bail as follows: $5,000 unsecured, urinalysis and drug rehabilitation treatment, if deemed so necessary. Defendant cannot reside at the Turabo Heights Public Housing Project. If qualified by USPO, the defendant's uncle will be his third party custodian. Standard conditions of release apply. Must remain studying. (Court Reporter FTR.) Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Arraignment as to Joseph Caballero-Colon (16) Count 1,2,3,4,5 held on 8/12/2013. Present: AUSA Teresa Zapata and defense counsel Rafael Anglada. Defendant assisted by Court Interpreter. USPO Carolina Aparicio also present. Plea of Not Guilty is entered as to all counts. Defense is granted seven (7) days to obtain discovery and fourteen (14) days thereafter to file all motions. The case is referred to Judge Jay Garcia-Gregory for trial setting thereafter. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Arraignment as to Jose Antonio Merced-Espada (50) Count 1,2,3,4,5 held on 8/12/2013. Present: SAUSA Alberto Lopez and defense counsel Luis Guzman. Defendant assisted by Court Interpreter. USPO Carolina Aparicio also present. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment. The case is referred to Judge Jay Garcia-Gregory for trial setting thereafter. As to detention, defense argues requests that conditions of release be fixed. Defendant has family ties and can relocate. Government's proffer heard and requests detention. The Court set bail as follows: $5,000 ($1,000 cash or secured and remaining $4,000 unsecured). Electronic monitoring device is imposed for a period of six (6) months and defendant is to pay 50% of the cost. Defendant cannot reside at the Turabo Heights Public Housing Project. Urinalysis and drug rehabilitation treatment are imposed. Defendant is to seek employment and provide evidence of efforts made to secure an employment. (Court Reporter FTR.) The Government has 7 days to produce discovery and the defense has 14 days thereafter to file motions. Case is referred to Judge Garcia for further proceedings. As to detention, defense counsel argued in favor of bail. The government requested detention. The Court imposed bail in the amount of $10,000 of which $5,000 will be cash or secured and $5,000 unsecured, drug testing and if deemed necessary by the USPO drug treatment, mental health evaluation and treatment, employment, defendant was allowed to assist his wife in the business they own, defendant shall not reside or enter any of the areas covered by the indictment, plus all other standard conditions of release. (Court Reporter FTR.)Hearing set for 01:30.Hearing held at 01:46.Hearing ended at 01:59.Interpreter Enith Valdes. (ft) (Entered: 08/19/2013)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez-Rive:Initial Appearance as to Jorge Gomez-Orta held on 8/22/2013. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Arraignment/Bail Hearings as to Jaime Omar Rodriguez-Negron (31) Count 1,2,3,4,5 held on 9/23/2013. AUSA Michael Bagge and defense counsel Olga Shepard were present. As to Arraignment, the Court finds defendant competent at this time. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment. Plea of Not Guilty is entered. Defense is granted seven (7) days to obtain discovery and fourteen (14) days thereafter to file all motions. The case is referred to  the Judge for trial setting thereafter. As to Bail, defense counsel proffered that defendant's main residence is in Connecticut, but has some family in Puerto Rico. Defense counsel agreed with the pretrial report and requested the Court to grant the same. The Government proffered that this is a presumption case, defendant depends on the Government to sustain himself and moved for detention. After hearing the parties, the Court agreed with the Government and hard to craft any condition at this time. The Court ordered defendant detained without bail. Defense counsel requested a reconsideration until she meets with family members. The Court will be willing to reopen the matter of bail once counsel files a motion. (Court Reporter FTR/bg.) Hearing set for 09:15. Hearing held at 10:00. Hearing ended at 10:09. Interpreter N/A. (br) (Entered: 09/23/2013)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Arraignment/Bail Hearings as to Victor M. Baez- Martinez (51) Count 1,2,3,4,5 held on 9/24/2013. AUSA Teresa Zapata and defense counsel Mariela Maestre were present. As to Arraignment, the Court finds defendant competent at this time. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment. Plea of Not Guilty is entered. Defense is granted seven (7) days to obtain discovery and fourteen (14) days thereafter to file all motions. The case is referred to the Judge for trial setting thereafter. As to Bail, defense counsel presented documentary evidence to rebut the pretrial report information and moved for bail. The Government was heard by proffer and moved for detention without bail due to danger to the community and risk of flight. After hearing the parties, the Court agreed with the Government and the pretrial report. The Court made findings and ordered defendant detained without bail pending trial. Minutes will be sent to MDC to provide mental evaluation and and be afforded treatment. (MDC by e-mail) (Court Reporter FTR/bg.) Hearing set for 09:15. Hearing held at 10:21. Hearing ended at 10:45. Interpreter Carlos Ravelo. (br) (Entered: 09/27/2013)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Arraignment/Detention Hearing as to Francisco J. Matos-Vazquez (74) Count 1,2,3,4,5 held on 11/7/2013. SAUSA Max Perez and defense counsel Carlos Beck were present. As to Arraignment, the Court finds defendant competent at this time. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment. Plea of Not Guilty is entered. Defense is granted seven (7) days to obtain discovery and fourteen (14) days thereafter to file all motions. The case is referred to the Judge for trial setting thereafter. As to Detention, defense counsel was heard by proffer and moved for bail. The Government proffered defendant's role and/or participation and moved for detention. After listening to the parties, the Court ordered defendant detained without bail pending trial. (Court Reporter FTR/bg.) Hearing set for 02:00. Hearing held at 02:36. Hearing ended at 02:53. Interpreter Hilda Gutierrez. (br) (Entered: 11/07/2013)

ORDER denying 527 Motion for Reconsideration as to Juan R. Matos-Vazquez (23). The court reaffirms its previous conclusion that the defendant does not pose a risk of flight, but that there are no conditions or combination of conditions that can reasonably assure the safety of the community. (ECF Nos. 302, 457). The defendant does make a convincing argument that the evidence against him regarding his involvement with firearms in the pending case is weak, as it appears to boil down to only the testimony of one person without any further corroboration from other sources. It is also noted that defendant has not been charged in count six of the indictment which directly relates to use of firearms in furtherance of a drug trafficking crime. The defendant's criminal history detailed in the original detention order (ECF No. 302) which includes, inter alia, firearms and an arrest while under supervision or probation, however, dissuades the court from granting conditions of release. Furthermore, although defendant presents evidence of a certificate received on March 13, 2007 regarding his participation or enrollment in religious training (ECF No. 527-4), it is also noted that the government has proffered that there are three witnesses that indicate that the defendant was a runner of the drug trafficking organization, conspiracy that according to the indictment transpired between the years 2005 and 2013. Although the court departs from the findings of the U.S. Pretrial Services Office regarding the concern of risk of flight, it concurs with the recommendation of the U.S. Pretrial Services Office that the defendant ought to remain detained pending trial due to the concern pertaining to the community's safety. Signed by US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez on 3/12/14. (Lopez, Marcos) (Entered: 03/12/2014)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez-Rive:Change of plea as to Roberto Lozada-Santiago (7) scheduled for 4/7/2014, but not held. Present were AUSA Carlos Cardona and Mr. Fernando Carlo. Defendant was present and under custody. Mr. Carlo addressed the Court stating that defendant had informed him that he was not signing the plea offered by the Government, and that he would be filing a motion to withdraw as counsel due to irreconcilable differences with defendant. The Court inquired from defendant whether he was asking for more time to consider the plea offer. Defendant addressed the Court stating his reasons for wanting a new attorney. The Court then vacated today's hearing and ordered that the case be returned to the Presider for his decision as to Mr. Carlo's motion. Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory: Sentencing held on 8/11/2014 for Heriberto Claudio-Abreu (14). Present: AUSA Alberto Lopez & Atty. Joseph Laws. Defendant present U/C. Counts 1, 6, Impr. for 60 months as to count | and 60 months as to count 6, to be served consecutively with each other for a total term of 120 months. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez-Rive:Change of Plea Hearing as to Nestor L. Merced- Nieves (9) held on 8/21/2014. Present were AUSA Alberto Lopez and Ms. Laura Maldonado. Dft was present and under custody. Waiver of JT and consent to proceed before a U. S. Magistrate Judge was filed and accepted in open court. The defendant is found competent to understand the proceedings. He is advised of the maximum penalties he's facing, his constitutional rights, consequences of waiving said rights and the applicable statutory guidelines. After hearing the parties, the Magistrate Judge will issue a Report and Recommendation to Judge Garcia so that the guilty plea as to count One (1) of the Indictment be accepted. The Court orders the preparation of the Pre-Sentence Report. Sentencing Hearing to be set by Judge Garcia. Defendant to remain under custody. Ms Maldonado requested that defendant be allowed to stay in PR until after sentencing so that he can finalize some arrangements which had to be done regarding his newborn baby. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez-Rive:Change of plea hearing as to Ramon L. Massa- Gonzalez (5)scheduled for 11/7/2014, but not held. Present were AUSA Teresa Zapata and Mr. Hector Deliz. Defendant was present and under custody. Mr. Deliz stated for the record that they were not ready to proceed with today's hearing since they were still in conversations with the prosecutor and in negotiations. AUSA Zapata requested that, since they had not been able to reach an agreement, the case be referred back to Judge Garcia so that this defendant be included in the December jury trial already scheduled. Sidebar held. After conferring with counsel, the Court returned the case back to Judge Garcia so that he can either schedule this defendant for trial or extend the time for further plea negotiations and referred the case back to this Court for plea hearing, if necessary. Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory: Sentencing held on 11/13/2014 for Sixto Medina-Gonzalez (12). Present: AUSA Alberto Lopez & Atty. Anita Hill. Defendant present U/C. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of the defense. Defendant's allocution heard. A two level reduction under Amendment 782 of the USSG was applied for a total offense level of 23. Count 1, Impr for 78 months. Counsel for the defendant requested reconsideration of the sentence imposed as to count 1. The request was granted. Counts 1, 6, Impr. for 70 months as to count 1, and 60 months as to count 6, to be served consecutively to each other for a total of 130 months. The Court credited the defendant for the time already served in 12-cr-774-01(DRD), which is relevant conduct; pursuant to the USSG 5(g)1.3(b). SRT of 8 years as to count 1, and 5 years as to count 6, to be served concurrently with each other. No fine. SMA $200.00; Counts 2, 3, 4, 5, dismissed as requested by the government. (Court Reporter Donna Prather.)Hearing set for 03:00.Hearing held at 04:06.Hearing ended at 04:38 Interpreter Felix Toledo. (ab) (Entered: 11/21/2014)

She waived the reading of the Indictment and entered a plea of not guilty as to all counts. The parties will have 7 days for discovery and 14 days thereafter to file any motions. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Arraignment/Bail Hearings as to Carlos Rivera- Velazquez (10) Count 1,2,3,4,5 held on 7/23/2015. AUSA Alberto Lopez and defense counsel Frank Inserni were present. As to Arraignment, the Court finds defendant competent at this time. Defendant waived the reading of the Indictment. Plea of Not Guilty is entered. During the colloquy, the Court asked defendant if he understood what he was being charged and the maximum penalties, for defendant answered in the affirmative. Defense is granted seven (7) days to obtain discovery and fourteen (14) days thereafter to file all motions. The case is referred to the Judge for trial setting thereafter. As to Bail, the Government moved for detention. Defense counsel had no evidence to contest the presumption, but reserved the right to reopen the matter of bail. Reservation was noted by the Court. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Silvia Carreno-Coll: Motion Hearing as to Ramon L. Massa-Gonzalez (5) held on 11/4/2015 re 2501 MOTION to Appoint Counsel filed by Ramon L. Massa-Gonzalez. present were AUSA Teresa Zapata and defense counsel Hector Deliz. The defendant was U/C, present in court and assisted by the Court Interpreter. Colloquy held between the Court and the defendant regarding his knowledge of the charges against him, consequences and penalties he is facing and the basis for his request to remove counsel Deliz as his defense counsel. After hearing defendant's allegations, as well as hearing from the Government and defense counsel, the Court found that there was no evidence of ineffective counsel assistance and thus, no basis to change defense counsel. Mr. Deliz will continue representing defendant Massa-Gonzalez. Motion at Docket No. 2501 was denied. (Court Reporter DCR.) Hearing set for 9:15 am. Hearing held at 9:48 am. Hearing ended at 10:03 am. Interpreter Janis Palma. (cmd) (Entered: 11/04/2015)

Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of the defense. Defendant's allocution was heard. The Court imposed sentence as to Count(s) 1s, Impr Term: Forty-eight (48) months (time served to be credited), SRT: Six (6) years, SMA: $100.00. Count(s) 1, 2, 2s, 3, 3s, 4, 4s, 5, 5s, 6s, Disposed by request of the Government. All terms and conditions are specified in the judgment form. The defendant was advised of his right to appeal. (USPO Deni Rodriguez.) (Court Reporter Cindy Brown.) Hearing set for 02:00. Hearing held at 02:58. Hearing ended at 03:21. Interpreter Marie Hernandez (assisted). (br) (Entered: 12/29/2015)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Camille L. Velez-Rive:Motion Hearing as to Israel Banks-Jimenez (88) held on 1/22/2016 re 2780 MOTION to Appoint Counsel filed by Israel Banks-Jimenez. Present were AUSA Jose Contreras and Ms Laura Maldonado. Defendant was present and under custody. Ms. Maldonado requested that the hearing be ex-parte. After hearing defense counsel's reason, the Court denied the request. Ms Maldonado explained that she had met with the defendant and discussed the contents of the motion he had filed, but it was her impression that he needed a new attorney. AUSA Contreras argued in favor of Ms Maldonado remaining as defendant's counsel. The Court inquired as to defendant's wishes and he stated that he would like to keep Ms Maldonado as his counsel. Ms Maldonado requested a few minutes to confer with defendant, and the Court granted the request. After a short break, the hearing resumed and the Court once again asked defendant his wish. Defendant answered that he wanted Ms Maldonado to be his attorney. Ms Maldonado stated that she had no problem to continue representing defendant. The Court denied the pro se motion filed by defendant under docket 2780. (Court Reporter -DCR.)Hearing set for 09:00.Hearing held at 10:12.Hearing ended at 10:33 Interpreter -Heidi Cazes. (yr) (Entered: 01/22/2016)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory: Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Francisco J. Matos- Vazquez (74) held on 6/7/2017. AUSA Teresa Zapata and AFPD Carlos Vazquez were present. Defendant was present, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Defense counsel requested that defendant be placed in an in-patient drug treatment program. The government requested revocation, since it is mandatory under the statute and, if defendant were granted to an in-patient treatment, that he be discharged directly to the program. The government had no objection for time served. Defense counsel was heard and requested the Court not to revoke defendant. After having heard both parties in this case, the Court finds that Mr. Matos- Vazquez violated the conditions of the imposed supervised release term by engaging in technical violations described on the motion filed by the United States Probation Officer on December 21, 2016, [Docket 3396]. However, the Court revoked the supervised release term at this time and sentenced the defendant to time served. All terms and conditions are modified and specified in the judgment form. The Court ordered the U.S. Marshals to produce defendant tomorrow to be picked up by Guarabi representatives and to start his in-patient treatment. (USPO Guillermo Arbona.) (Court Reporter Cindy Brown.) Hearing set for 02:30. Hearing held at 03:59. Hearing ended at 04:09. Interpreter Felix Toledo. (br) (Entered: 06/07/2017)
JUDGMENT ON REVOCATION as to Francisco J. Matos- Vazquez (74): TIME SERVED. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 6/7/2017. (br) (Entered: 06/07/2017)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory: Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Carlos R. Santos- Velazquez (69) held on 6/7/2017. AUSA Teresa Zapata and AFPD Jessica Earl were present. Defendant was present, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of the defense. The government agreed with defense that the defendant has a severe drug problem. The government recommended that when released from MDC that he be released directly to the program to attempt totally rehabilitation. Defendant's allocution was heard. After having heard the parties in this case, the Court finds that Mr. Santos Velzquez has violated the conditions of the supervised release term as cited in the motion filed by the U.S. Probation Officer on March 9, 2017. Therefore, the supervised release term imposed on January 7, 2015, is hereby revoked. Therefore, it is the judgment of this Court that the defendant is hereby committed to the custody of the Bureau of Prisons to be imprisoned for a term of four (4) months. Upon release from confinement, the defendant shall be placed on supervised release for a period of forty-eight (48) months. All terms and conditions are specified in the judgment form. The defendant was advised of his right to appeal. (USPO Norman Rosario.) (Court Reporter Cindy Brown.) Hearing set for 03:30. Hearing held at 03:45. Hearing ended at 03:59. Interpreter Felix Toledo. (br) (Entered: 06/08/2017)

AUSA Dina Avila and AFPD Franco Perez were present. Defendant was present, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Defense counsel informed that defendant will not be contesting, but requested that defendant be allowed to stay in Guarabi. The government requested that defendant be revoked, but do not have objection to the request as to the in- patient treatment and the time served. Defendant has a state court detainer and, although treatment has been provided, defendant fails to comply. After having heard defendant's counsel, the prosecutor and defendant's allocution, the Court finds that the defendant has violated the conditions of the supervised release term imposed on him, by possessing unlawful controlled substances, testing positive results on more than one (1) occasion to cocaine, and marihuana, not following the instructions of the U.S. Probation Officer and failing to report a change in address at least ten days prior as cited in the motion filed on March 9, 2017. The Court finds that defendant violated his release conditions and the supervised release term is hereby revoked. The Court imposed sentence to five (5) months of imprisonment and 6 years of supervised release term. All terms and conditions are specified in the judgment form. The defendant was advised of his right to appeal. (USPO Jose Lozada.) (Court Reporter Cindy Brown.) Hearing set for 03:00. Hearing held at 03:57. Hearing ended at 04:10. Interpreter Annie Flores. (br) (Entered: 07/10/2017)

Morgan: Preliminary Revocation Hearing re 3609 Notifying Violations to Conditions of Supervised Release Term as to Steven Velez-Lopez (53) held on 12/11/2018. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marshal D. Morgan:Preliminary Revocation Hearing as to Victor M. Baez- Martinez (51) held on 9/19/2019. Present: AUSA Jonathan Jacobson (for Teresa Zapata), defense counsel Diego Alcala and USPO Luis Santana. The defendant was present, under custody and assisted by a certified court interpreter. The defendant filed a Waiver of Preliminary Hearing Form. The Court approved the waiver and entered a finding of probable cause pursuant to Rules 5 and 32.1 of the Fed.R.Crim.P. The case was referred to Senior U.S. District Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory for Final Revocation Hearing. Attorney Alcala requested conditions of release pending the final hearing for the defendant to be able to benefit from inpatient treatment at the Guara-Bi Residential Program. USPO Santana recommended inpatient treatment. The Government had no objection. After having heard the parties, the Court ordered that the defendant be released to the Guara-Bi Program pending the final hearing. Attorney Alcala informed that his client was housed at the Bayamon 705 prison and was scheduled to be transferred today to the Salinas detention facility. He requested that the USM transfer his client to MDC so that Guara-Bi personnel might pick him up there. The Court instructed the USM to transfer the defendant to MDC if possible. If such transfer were not possible, the USM are to contact USPO Santana at 787-766-5596 to inform him of the defendant's location. (Court Reporter DCR-Courtroom 6.)Hearing set for 09:30.Hearing held at 10:40.Hearing ended at 10:56. Interpreter Felix Toledo. (lod) (Entered: 09/19/2019)

Minute Entry for proceedings held before Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory:Final Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Carlos R. Santos-Velazquez (69) held on 2/20/2020.Present were AUSA Cesar Rivera for Teresa Zapata, AFPD Sulay Rios and USPO Yaritza Feliciano. Defendant was under custody, present in Court and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Defendant does not contest the alleged violations. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of the defense. Defendants allocution heard. After hearing the parties, the Court revokes the previously imposed SRT and sentence defendant to (18) months (credit for time served in state prison that is 14 months, therefore he will be committed to 4 months with the date of release of March 12, 2020. ORDER as to Joel Davila-Ramos (48): GRANTING 3868 JOINT Motion Requesting Order of Revocation of supervised release and immediate sentence; NOTED 3873 Informative Motion filed by defendant. Upon review of defendant Joel Davila-Ramoss Joint Motion for Revocation of Supervised Release filed by both counsel for defendant and for the Government given the current Covid-19 emergency and defendant having waived his right to a hearing( as per representations made by his counsel) and there being no  objection by probation, in accordance with the case law from the First Circuit referenced in the motion, this Court hereby grants the request for revocation of supervised release, revokes the same, and sentences defendant Joel Davila-Ramos to the time already served and imposes a supervised release term of eight (8) years under the same terms and conditions imposed at his sentencing hearing and prevalent at the time of his arrest for his violation of supervised release. Judgment to be issued and entered forthwith. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 4/13/2020. (su) (Entered: 04/13/2020)

ORDER denying without prejudice Defendant (14) Heriberto Claudio-Abreu's 3880 and 3892 Motions. Defendant has failed to establish that compassionate release is warranted pursuant to 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Specifically, Defendant has failed to establish: (1) exhaustion of administrative remedies; (2) extraordinary and compelling reasons justifying a reduction in sentence; (3) that he does not pose a danger to the community; and (4) that a sentence reduction is consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements issued by the Sentencing Commission. Even assuming, without deciding, that the Court may excuse the failure to exhaust administrative remedies, Defendant's motion lacks specific information or evidence supporting the allegations of preexisting health conditions that would increase for Defendant the risks posed by COVID-19 infection beyond the risks posed to the general population. See United States v. Raia, 954 F.3d

597 (3d Cir. 2020) ("We do not mean to minimize the risks that COVID-19 poses in the federal prison system... But the mere existence of COVID-19 in society and the possibility that it may spread to a particular prison alone cannot independently justify compassionate release, especially considering BOP's statutory role, and its extensive and professional efforts to curtail the virus's spread."); United States v. Eberhart, 2020 WL 1450745, at *2 (N.D. Cal. Mar. 25, 2020) ("[A] reduction of sentence due solely to concerns about the spread of COVID-19 is not consistent with the applicable policy statement of the Sentencing Commission as required by  3582(c)(1)(A)."). Defendant may refile the present motion provided he submits evidence to satisfy the requirements of 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). USPO's 3918 MOTION in Compliance is noted. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 7/28/2020. (ERC) (Entered: 07/28/2020)

ORDER striking 3956 Informative Motion as to Heriberto Claudio-Abreu (14). Plaintiff's pro se status does not insulate him from complying with this Court's procedural rules. Ahmed v. Rosenblatt, 118 F.3d 886, 890 (1st Cir. 1997). In this district, all documents must be filed in English or accompanied by a certified English translation, as required by 48 U.S.C.  864 ("All pleadings and proceedings in the United States District Court for the District of Puerto Rico shall be conducted in the English language."); and Local Civil Rule 5(g) ("All documents not in the English language which are presented or filed, whether as evidence or otherwise, must be accompanied by a certified translation into English prepared by an interpreter certified by the Administrative Office of the United States Courts."). Plaintiff shall refile the Motion in the English language. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 9/10/2020. (ERC) (Entered: 09/10/2020)

ORDER denying without prejudice Defendant (2) Jose Gonzalez-Fuentes's 3967 Motion. Defendant has failed to show this Court has jurisdiction over his request for home confinement, considering that the BOP is solely responsible for determining an inmate's place of incarceration. See 18 U.S.C.  3621(b). Defendant has again not shown that compassionate relief is warranted as he did not establish: (1) exhaustion of administrative remedies; (2) extraordinary and compelling reasons justifying a reduction in sentence; (3) that he does not pose a danger to the community; and (4) that a sentence reduction is consistent with 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements issued by the Sentencing Commission. Defendant may refile the present motion provided he submits evidence to satisfy the requirements of 18 U.S.C. 3582(c)(1)(A). Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 9/18/2020. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez: Initial Appearance on Revocation of Supervised Release as to Victor M. Baez-Martinez (51) held on 2/2/2021. SAUSA Michelle Colon and AFPD Coral Rodriguez were present via VTC. Defendant was under custody, present and assisted by a certified court interpreter. All parties were present via VTC. Defendant voluntarily consented to the holding of the hearing via VTC. Defendant was advised of the SRT violations at ECF No. 4019 and his right to a preliminary hearing to determine whether his supervised release conditions have been violated. The Court deemed it appropriate to appoint counsel. The FPD was appointed to represent the defendant. Defendant was ordered temporarily detained. A preliminary revocation hearing was set for 2/11/2021 at 02:03 pm via VTC before US Magistrate Judge Marcos E. Lopez. If the government intends to call a witness that is not fluent in the English language, failure of the government to timely retain the services of an interpreter may result in the imposition of sanctions. As required by Rule 5(f), the United States is ordered to produce all exculpatory evidence to the defendant pursuant to Brady v. Maryland and its progeny. Not doing so in a timely manner may result in sanctions, including exclusion of evidence, adverse jury instructions, dismissal of charges and contempt proceedings. Court Reporter Zoom Recording. Hearing set for 02:00. Hearing held at 02:23. Hearing ended at 02:31. Interpreter Carlos Ravelo. (jjr) (Entered: 02/02/2021)

ORDER as to Heriberto Claudio-Abreu (14), granting Defendant's 3960 Motion for Reconsideration; and granting 4012 MOTION for Compassionate Release - 18 U.S.C. Section 3582(c)(1)(A). Defendant qualifies for relief under 18 U.S.C.  3582(c)(1)(A). First, Defendant has exhausted administrative remedies. Docket Nos. 4012 at 11, 4045 at 7-8. Second, the Court finds that Defendant's family circumstances qualify as extraordinary and compelling reasons for a reduction in sentence as the severity of Defendant's spouse's medical condition is interfering with her ability to care for herself and their two children, and Defendant would be the only available caretaker for his spouse and children. See USSG  1B1.13, cmt. n.1(C); Docket Nos. 3960 at 2, 4045 at 4-6. Third, the Court finds that Defendant is not a danger to others or the community. While Defendant has had been sanctioned for five incidents while serving his sentence, Docket No. 4045 at 7, Defendant has demonstrated commitment to his rehabilitation: he has completed education courses (parenting, business, and enrolled in GED), received vocational training (painting, construction, etc.) and correctional treatment, and been employed at BOP (currently assigned yard detail). Docket Nos. 4012 at 14-15, 4045 at 7. USPO states that Defendant has positive family support and can continue his path of rehabilitation with Court imposed supervision. Docket No. 4045 at 6. Defendant is a first-time offender who is now 36 years old, /d., and as such, presents a low risk of recidivism given his age and criminal history score. He is currently classified at security level "low". /d. While Defendants "offense involved firearms, there is no evidence that he was linked to violent acts within the conspiracy. /d.. USPO made the overall assessment that Defendant is not a danger to the community. /d. at 7. And finally, the Court finds that a reduction in Defendant's sentence is consistent with the factors set forth in 18 U.S.C. 3553(a) and the applicable policy statements issued by the Sentencing Commission. As a result of the COVID-19 emergency, Defendant's sentence has been unusually harsh, especially in light of Defendant's mental health conditions and how they have been exacerbated by the safety measures imposed to protect inmates (lockdowns, inability to communicate with family members, limited access to legal or social visits). Docket No. 4012 at 13-14. Defendant has already completed 75% of his sentence of his 120-month sentence, and given the circumstances, a modified sentence would still reflect the seriousness of the offense, promote respect for the law, and provide just punishment for the offense. For these reasons, Defendant's motions are hereby GRANTED. Defendant's sentence of imprisonment shall be reduced to time served with supervised release term conditions modified to impose curfew for twelve (12) months along with electronic monitoring, allowing Defendant to leave his home from 6:00 A.M. to 6:00 P.M. Amended Judgment shall be entered accordingly. Signed by Judge Jay A. Garcia-Gregory on 2/12/2021. (ERC) (Entered: 02/12/2021)

Present were AUSA Maria Montanez, APFD Joseph Niskar and USPO Luis Santana. Defendant under custody, present in court via VTC and assisted by an official court interpreter. The defendant waived his right to appear physically for this proceeding and agreed to proceed with the via VTC due to the COVID-19 emergency and pursuant to CARES Act,  15002(b)(1). Defendant does not contest the alleged violations. Statements in support of mitigation of punishment heard on behalf of the defense. Defendants allocution heard. After hearing the parties, the Court revokes the previously imposed SRT and sentenced defendant to 4 months of imprisonment and SRT of 60 months. All terms and conditions are specified in the judgment form. Defendant was advised of his right to appeal. Minute Entry for proceedings held before US Magistrate Judge Giselle Lopez-Soler: Show Cause Hearing re Revocation of Supervised Release as to Israel Arroyo-Serrano (82) held on 6/29/2021 via VTC. Present were AUSA John Hutchins, AFPD Lauren Rosen and USPO George Maymi. Defendant was present O/B and assisted by a certified court interpreter. Defendant waived his right to appear physically at the hearing and consented to proceed via VTC. Defendant was advised of the SRT violations as alleged in the motion filed at Docket No. 4145 and as to his rights. Defendant will continue to be represented by the FPD's Office. Pursuant to the Due Process Protections Act, Pub. L. No. 116-182, 134 Stat. 894 (Oct. 21, 2020) and Rule 5(f) of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure, the United States is reminded of its obligation to disclose in a timely manner all exculpatory evidence to the defendant(s], that is, all evidence that is favorable to the defendant[s] or tends to cast doubt on the United States case, as required by Brady v. Maryland, 373 U.S. 83 (1963) and its progeny. Failure to comply with this order may result in consequences, including, but not limited to, the reversal of any conviction, the exclusion of evidence, adverse jury instructions, dismissal of charges, contempt proceedings, disciplinary action, and/or sanctions by the Court. As to detention, the Government informed the Court that they're not moving for detention. After hearing the parties, the Court ordered that the defendant remain under the same conditions of supervised release. In view that Defendant is under conditions of release, he is not entitled to a preliminary revocation hearing (see F.R.Cr.P. 32.1(b)(1)(A)). This matter is thus referred to the attention of the presiding District Judge for a final revocation hearing. (Court Reporter ZoomGov Recording.) Hearing set for 10:00. Hearing held at 10:43. Hearing ended at 10:49. Interpreter Felix Toledo. (rom) (Entered: 06/30/2021)
